channel.title: INfinance
channel.description: This is a randomly ordered feed of the most recent entries from INfinance, skipping any feeds with errors.

item.title: Super Micro’s looming deadline fuels fear of delisting. Here’s what that means.
item.description: Super Micro’s stock was already delisted once before, in a drawn-out process with various extensions.

item.title: One strategist lifts recession probability to 75% after Trump’s win and recommends how to position for it
item.description: The benefit from tax cuts may be outweighed by the damage done by tariffs

item.title: Treasury yields slip ahead of retail sales report
item.description: Bond yields slipped Friday as investors unwound some of the hawkish reaction to Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell’s remarks.

item.title: The $55 Billion Customer Exodus Rocking Franklin Templeton
item.description: The Justice Department and other federal agencies are investigating trades by Wamco’s star fund manager.

item.title: America's Homes Are Piggy Banks That Few People Can Afford to Raid
item.description: Only a minority of mainly older homeowners are in a position to take advantage of the historic run-up in house prices.

item.title: Homeowners are using this hack to cut their mortgage payments in half — and chip away at the housing shortage
item.description: California homeowners are embracing tiny homes in their backyards. The movement has offered a blueprint for cities across the U.S. that are grappling ...

item.title: Is Anyone Crazy Enough to Audit Super Micro Computer?
item.description: After Ernst & Young walked away, all eyes should be on its previous auditor. The risks include Nasdaq delisting.

item.title: U.S. Two-30-Year Treasury Yield Spread Has Room to Widen
item.description: It is somewhat surprising that longer-dated Treasury yields haven’t been under more pressure over the past few days, BlueBay said, and it continues to...

item.title: Dollar Might Reverse Lower After Post-Election Gains

item.title: Why no more than 60% of your retirement money belongs in stocks
item.description: Bonds have kept pace with stocks throughout U.S. market history.
